pullRequest.body:
The "admit" linter flags usages of the `admit` tactic.

The tactics `admit` and `sorry` are synonyms.
The use of `sorry` is much more common and should be preferred.

---
See also [zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113489-new-members/topic/.E2.9C.94.20difference.20between.20sorry.20and.20admit/near/459519146)

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [ec6d548004](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15667/commits/ec6d5480049e0108ba8da35ed92ae3ac9ff97921)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|1|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.Linter.AdmitLinter`|2|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ admitLinter`
`+ getAdmit`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Oh, and another question I realised (sorry!, this is really the last one): would you like to add a test for this linter, i.e. demonstrate that the "real" admit is actually linted? (`test/lint.lean` has a few examples to copy from; feel free to ask if you're not sure how to add one and I (and I presume Damiano as well) will be happy to help.

> Oh, and another question I realised (sorry!, this is really the last one): would you like to add a test for this linter, i.e. demonstrate that the "real" admit is actually linted? (`test/lint.lean` has a few examples to copy from; feel free to ask if you're not sure how to add one and I (and I presume Damiano as well) will be happy to help.


@grunweg It seems I have to import something into `test/Lint.lean`? Right now the linter doesn't work in that file. The `refine'` linter that I copied this from also doesn't seem to have a test?

I took a last look: this PR looks good to me. I directly pushed a commit adapting this PR to the (very soon landing) PR #15771, and added a test.
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.

> > Oh, and another question I realised (sorry!, this is really the last one): would you like to add a test for this linter, i.e. demonstrate that the "real" admit is actually linted? (`test/lint.lean` has a few examples to copy from; feel free to ask if you're not sure how to add one and I (and I presume Damiano as well) will be happy to help.
> 
> @grunweg It seems I have to import something into `test/Lint.lean`? Right now the linter doesn't work in that file. The `refine'` linter that I copied this from also doesn't seem to have a test?

Sorry, it seems my comment was misleading. The `refine'` linter is tested `tests/RefineLinter`: I just pushed a commit adding a test for this linter.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10601145803/job/29380297313)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10601145803/job/29380296842)

Thanks for writing this linter!
I see this is in draft status, but took a look anyway. I have a couple of comments, but all of them are minor/should be quick to address.

Nice!

bors merge

Thanks for writing this linter!
I see this is in draft status, but took a look anyway. I have a couple of comments, but all of them are minor/should be quick to address.

Nice!

bors merge

Prefixing an actually used variable with an underscore looks slightly funny. What do you think about renaming `_stx` to `stx` instead, and using a different name below (or even just `stx` again, shadowing it - if that works)?
Also, use \maps, please.
done
Does this fit on one line? (The message looks good to me.)
For the other linters, this option is usually put outside of the `linterName` namespace. Did you change this for a reason?
I copied this from the refineLinter
@adomani was there a reason this was done for the refineLinter? Should we change it there, too? Or just here?

I don't have an opinion: I think that in copy-pasting something changed at one point and one of the two options became dominant!

Feel free to uniformize, if you want!
I adjusted this PR to handle namespaces like what most other linters seem to do.
Can you use the definition of admit instead of rolling your own? (Or is that the issue you're referring to in the description?)
Should you be the copyright holder? @adomani what do you think?
I agree: the copyright holder should probably be Adomas.  I also do not really pay much attention to the copyright section of the files anyway.

This setting enables the linter in *any* file which imports this (or a file importing this one). As you want ~all of mathlib to be linted, that implies projects *depending* on mathlib will also see this linter. The question to decide is whether this is what we want.
I tend towards "no": this is purely a decision about code style, which mathlib should not impose on other projects.
Thus, the ideal long-term fix is to *disable* this linter by default, but *enable* it in mathlib (and the archive and counterexamples).
That said: there's another PR open about doing exactly this - so you're very welcome to argue the other PR should modify this linter instead!
Mathlib does not allow commits that contain `sorry` or `admit` anyway. So I'm not sure what the linter would be doing in that case?

The linter would not affect code that gets merged into mathlib, but it would still highlight "in-development" `admit`s.  I also agree that the default value should be `false` anyway: the admit command is defined in core and it should really be the decision of the core developers if they want the `sorry`-synonym to continue existing or not.  The linter gives the opportunity to projects downstream of mathlib to choose whether or not they allow it.
Set default to `false`.
Do you think this should be `getAdmit` instead?

```suggestion
    if kind == ``Lean.Parser.Tactic.tacticAdmit then rargs.push stx else rargs
```
Then you can delete your `admit` definition.

Or, even better, use a syntax quotation like
```lean
partial
def getadmit (stx : Syntax) : Array Syntax :=
  if let `(tactic| admit) := stx then
    #[stx]
  else if let .node _ _ args := stx then
    (args.map getadmit).flatten
  else
    #[]
```
Even shorter:
```lean
partial
def getadmit (stx : Syntax) : Array Syntax :=
  if let `(tactic| admit) := stx then
    #[stx]
  else
    stx.foldArgs (fun arg r => r ++ getadmit arg) #[]
```
Used the last suggestion.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: linter for `admit` (use `sorry` instead)
